title: RSPCA demands phasing out of caged eggs in developing new poultry standards - ABC Rural - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

organizations.name: the new zealand national scientific advisory committee

text:
By Sarina Locke Updated February 15, 2017 14:28:00 Map: Sydney 2000 
The RSPCA has threatened to walk out of developing new poultry standards unless it considers the phasing out of caged eggs. 
It follows a letter written by animal welfare scientists some months ago, expressing concern their research on egg production had been selectively used to bolster the case for the caged egg industry. 
The scientists have since taken part in revising the draft paper. 
The RSPCA hopes to push the Animal Welfare Task Group to consider the end of caged hens. 
"Quite frankly, battery cages are extremely cruel," said Dr Jed Goodfellow, a senior policy officer with the RSPCA. 
"The science internationally is showing us that hens suffer inside battery cages. 
"They are prevented from engaging in any form of natural behaviour and even the ability to extend their limbs. 
"The New Zealand National Scientific Advisory Committee, the EU Sceintific Veterinary Commission [and] Canada's Animal Care Council have all concluded that battery cages have no future in those countries and are phasing it out. 
"The EU has already done it. To suggest Australia can reach a different conclusion is quite unbelievable." 
The animal welfare scientists, Dr Jean-Loup Rault and Professor Paul Hemsworth of the University of Melbourne, have reportedly been satisfied with the revised draft paper. 
But that's not enough for Dr Goodfellow. 
"What we're not satisfied with is that the standards still do not reflect the science," he said. 
"Yes the support paper for cages has now been revised including an acknowledgement that the hen welfare cannot be met in a barren battery cage. 
"But the draft standards do not reflect that conclusion." 
It's a period of major change for the egg industry, as it responds to a consumer shift to free range. 
The share of caged eggs sales last year fell below 50 per cent for the first time. 
The RSPCA is now threatening to quit the process unless an objective scientific review of cages is done, and the phasing out of cages is begun. 
"If the standards are not based on current science then the RSPCA will reconsider whether it plays a role on setting the animal welfare standard," Dr Goodfellow said. 
When asked directly if the RSPCA would walk out, he said "potentially". "Eggshaustive" process says egg farm lobby 
Caged egg farmers last year spoke out and said their production method was misunderstood and demonised . 
The industry lobby group Egg Farmers of Australia has defended the process of reviewing animal welfare as independent and run by government departmental secretaries. 
With an exaggerated emphasis on eggs, Egg Farmers of Australia chief executive John Dunn said the process was "eggshaustive, and important". 
"It's facilitated by state and territory governments from across Australia and will involve discussion with industry, government and animal welfare," he said. 
"It's a collaboration and we think it's robust." 
Mr Dunn said egg farmers would continue with caged production, because it was cheaper for consumers. 
"We still have 24 per cent of supermarket shoppers who always buy caged eggs," he said. 
"It's important to understand their motivation as it's the cheapest form of protein it continues to be an important staple in a healthy diet." 
Animal Health Authority, the project manager for establishing the new guidelines for poultry welfare, said it was keen to keep the RSPCA at the table. 
"The process isn't flawed from the start, and the science is robust, and caged eggs was part of this process," chief executive Kathleen Plowman said. 
"There was a concern that they did raise and I do believe that it has been sufficiently reviewed. 
"And in fact one of the scientists who originally brought this to our attention, Dr Rault, he was involved in the revision of the supporting paper to address these concerns, to make sure the latest scientific evidence on caged systems was included."
